seg.seg: ... Look here, oh teacher! || In the Gautamakapila [tune] ||
... fruit of the gift is to be obtained in 1,000 births. Ten
... he gives, of that there is no measure nor number. 1. He who gives
... he will acquire (divine) and human happiness as much as he wants. Again and again
He will acquire (divine) and human happiness as much as he wants. (29)
(the doctrine). If he happily reaches extinction, why should a giver not rejoice? 2. ||
If he happily reaches extinction, why [should] a giver not rejoice?
... making (Metrak’)s hand touch his own forehead, (Bādhari) says: Good, my son! At this time I (have acquired?) great
(joy) ... || In the ...r [tune] || Five hundred disciples I have given to you with joy for instruction. The entire chain of beings of the triple universe ... to you ...
... you are for me; from the good ones such as you may there not be separation for me! 1. || Having heard that,
... that one, Bādhari the teacher! Why that? When all the living beings of the chain of existences ... Bā(dhari’s)
... the noble Metrak is worthy of being the teacher of us without a question – of Bādhari alone ...
... (A)jita says: When the noble Metrak became an eight-year old, just at that time
... he surpassed the Brahmins. Why that? He (had studied) the eighteen treatises concerning Vidyāsthānas.
... he, being eight years old, surpassed in all respects
... the virtues of the noble Metrak. Why that?

; MaitrHami 1, 8-9

The parallel Uyghur (till I, 10b30) version is badly damaged. In many lines, only one or a few words are left; afterwards, the entire leaves 11 and 12 are lost. It therefore cannot help us to understand the Tocharian version.
This fragment contains part of the first act of the Maitreyasamitināṭaka; a parallel text is (b8 here = : b3). An Uy. parallel is MaitrHami I, 8a4-9a22. See also 193-4.
The translation and the following commentary are adapted from 30.
The verb pälkār is found complete in : a3. Gautamakapila: two stanzas of 4 x 14 (7/7) syllables, cf. : a3.
The meaning is obscure. Maybe it means: “he gives numberless alms”.
The first word can probably be restored to märkampal.
The beginning of this line can be complemented according to MaitrHami 1, 8 a 28–30 (cf. 18).
puk is singular; after that, the most probable analysis is: tñy plus the beginning of another word (a verb?).

In the beginning here, according to MaitrHami 1, 8b2–3 (cf. 18), one can complete tsopats(\) or tsopatsäṃ. The clause päñ känt to āklässi is treated according to MaitrHami 1, 8b4–6 (cf. 18). End of the first pāda of a stanza of 4 x 12 (5/7) syllables, the name of which is incomplete.
krañsäṣ, to be restored as krañ(c)säṣ. The obl. pl. of kāsu is krañcäs. According to the context, krañsäṣ here can only be the abl. pl. of kāsu.
k_uyālte: sic! The reading is sure, against expected k_uyalte, as elsewhere.

Cf. MaitrHami 1, 8b19–20 (Cf. 18): “our teacher Bādhari the Brahmin becomes the teacher of all.” kuc prakṣäl, literally: “what is to ask?” It might be suitable to translate it into: “Let alone, how much less”. Cf. : b6: kuc prakṣäl pācräṣ.
kakäṃ must be an independent word: a verb, 3rd sg. active, and past tense, A equivalent of B preterite kyāna.
vidyasthānä-śāsträntu: cf. MaitrHami 1, 9a1–2 (cf. 18). Skt. vidyāsthāna- “domain of knowledge”; there are 18 of them.
In Tocharian the number is put behind the words, not as in English before the words.
vatstsahā_r\: corrected after 281.
Probably śtä(k), corresponding to B śatka, preterite of kätk-, cf. āsuk kätk- “to surpass” (cf. 83).
kāswoneytu: for kāswoneyäntu, pl. nom.-obl.; cf. kāswneyntu in : b3.

a3. The meaning is obscure. Maybe it means: “he gives numberless alms”.

a7. puk is singular; after that, the most probable analysis is: tñy plus the beginning of another word (a verb?).

a8. krañsäṣ, to be restored as krañ(c)säṣ. The obl. pl. of kāsu is krañcäs. According to the context, krañsäṣ here can only be the abl. pl. of kāsu.

b3. kakäṃ must be an independent word: a verb, 3rd sg. active, and past tense, A equivalent of B preterite kyāna.

b5. In Tocharian the number is put behind the words, not as in English before the words.

b7-8. Probably śtä(k), corresponding to B śatka, preterite of kätk-, cf. āsuk kätk- “to surpass” (cf. [[Krause and Thomas, TEB II]]: 83).

b8. kāswoneytu: for kāswoneyäntu, pl. nom.-obl.; cf. kāswneyntu in [[A 293]]: b3.

The parallel Uyghur (till I, 10b30) version is badly damaged. In many lines, only one or a few words are left; afterwards, the entire leaves 11 and 12 are lost. It therefore cannot help us to understand the Tocharian version.

a1. The verb pälkār is found complete in [[A 293]]: a3. Gautamakapila: two stanzas of 4 x 14 (7/7) syllables, cf. [[A 293]]: a3.

a5. The first word can probably be restored to märkampal.

a6. The beginning of this line can be complemented according to MaitrHami 1, 8 a 28–30 (cf. [[Ji et al. 1998]]: 18).

a7. In the beginning here, according to MaitrHami 1, 8b2–3 (cf. [[Ji et al. 1998]]: 18), one can complete tsopats(\) or tsopatsäṃ. The clause päñ känt to āklässi is treated according to MaitrHami 1, 8b4–6 (cf. [[Ji et al. 1998]]: 18). End of the first pāda of a stanza of 4 x 12 (5/7) syllables, the name of which is incomplete.

b1. k_uyālte: sic! The reading is sure, against expected k_uyalte, as elsewhere.

b2. Cf. MaitrHami 1, 8b19–20 (Cf. [[Ji et al. 1998]]: 18): “our teacher Bādhari the Brahmin becomes the teacher of all.” kuc prakṣäl, literally: “what is to ask?” It might be suitable to translate it into: “Let alone, how much less”. Cf. [[YQ II.3]]: b6: kuc prakṣäl pācräṣ.

b4-5. vidyasthānä-śāsträntu: cf. MaitrHami 1, 9a1–2 (cf. [[Ji et al. 1998]]: 18). Skt. vidyāsthāna- “domain of knowledge”; there are 18 of them.
